content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think tht's a very good probleme to be setted and probably needed just harder set of tests well done ✅

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: J'accepte cette contribution car il s'agit d'un problème comptable courant et relativement simple et intéressant, susceptible d'être rencontré fréquemment.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good proposition. Episode 2 needed to complicate the test set

Title
* Please fix the typo: accouting => accounting.

* What are the planned future parts of the puzzle (since this is labelled as Part 1)?

Goal
* It feels odd to me that there are multiple bank statements to match multiple invoices. Do you mean multiple payment entries on a single bank statement to match multiple invoices?

* Please change all instances of "combine"/"combination" to "match".

* Please change "[[lettering*]]" to "<<lettering>>" (no *, no variable format, you may format it in <<bold>> or leave it unformatted).

* Please change "*lettering" to "Lettering" and move the last paragraph up so that it becomes the second paragraph.

* Please exclude "list of" from the variable format (twice).

* Please exclude "a" from the variable format.

* Before the example, please explain how association should be done (as per @cedricdd's comment), and what/how letters should be assigned to each combination.

* Please fix the typo: Exemple => Example.

* Please do not format "Exemple:" as a [[variable]]. You may format it in <<bold>> or leave it unformatted.

* Please change "invoice's" to "invoice".

* Please change "statement's" to "statement".

Input
* Please change "Integer" to "An integer" (twice) for consistency.

Output
* Please delete "Next".

* Please add "One match "

* Please format "-" as a {{constant}} and remove the quotation marks.

* Please add "Invoice amounts are separated by a space."

Constraints
* Please add "There are no cases where a match can only be made between multiple bank statements with one or multiple invoices, e.g. 2 4 - 6 or 2 4 - 1 5."

* Please add "1 ≤ [[K]] ≤ 26" (so we don't have to worry what letter to use if K is greater than 26).

Cases
* Please make Validator 4 a bit more different from Test 4, by changing all statement and invoice amounts to be different between the two cases.

Thanks.

Hi,

You need to define the rules in the statement. Why is an invoice associated with a given statement and not another one.
For example why isn't that a valid output for validator 4:
A 10 - 7 3
B 24 - 10 14
C 12 - 12
Can you explain further? I've read and reread it several times, but I've understood absolutely nothing.

Hi,
Yes of course, it was a first draft.
The principle is similar to the lettering in accounting domain.
The objective is to combine only one statement with one or more invoices and associate a letter to this combination.
In this exercise, we only have the amounts of these statements and invoices.

Hi,
Thanks for your comment !
You're right, so do I need to explain that the program must be based on the statement and that we combine invoices in the given order ?

Hi,
Thank you very much for your reply!
I updated everything, tell me if I did something wrong.

Regarding your question "What are the planned future parts of the puzzle?", I was already thinking about a second part, but now I think I need to wait until this one is published before thinking too much.

From your comment on the bank statement, you are right, I am confusing bank statement and payment entries.

Following my "list of" exclusion changes, I have a question: should I keep the [[payment entries]] or should I replace it with something else?

Forgive my English, I am aware that it is not very good.

Thank you for your reply. And no worries! Please feel free to ask if you have any questions!

As it's confirmed that we're matching the payment entries, various wordings should be updated accordingly:

Goal
* Suggest to add "on a bank statement" after "a list of [[payment entries]]" for clarity.

* "An association is done based on a statement and a letter is attached to it, next match invoices in the given order." This is still not very clear. You may rewrite it to something like this (and insert your instruction where indicated):

Matches are output in the same order of the [[payment entries]]. Letters are assigned to each match, starting with {{A}}, then {{B}} and so on. In case there are multiple ways to match a payment entry, [insert here how to decide which invoice(s) should be matched first].

* Example: Please change "statement" to "payment entry" (twice).

Input
* Line 2: Please change "bank statements" to "payment entries".

* Next N lines: Please change "the invoice" to "an invoice".

* Next M lines: Please change "the bank statement" to "a payment entry".

Output
* Please change "bank statement" to "payment entry".

* Please change "Statement and invoices" to "Payment entry amounts and invoice amounts".

Constraints
* Please change "bank statements" to "payment entries".

Thanks again.

Many thanks for your feedback.
It's very interesting to have your point of view on all this and to discuss with you.

By the way, I updated these changes.
Let me know if I can improve something.

About the difficulty, did I let it like that or change it to "easy"?

All right, looking better! Regarding your question, I believe it will depend on the cases. I'll write more about my thoughts in "Cases" section of this comment below.

Stub generator
* Please change "statement" to "paymentEntry".

Input
* Please change "[[statement]]" to "[[paymentEntry]]".

Goal
* Something is still missing. Please change "In case there are multiple ways to match a payment entry, invoice amounts are displayed in the given order." to:

In case a payment entry is matched to multiple invoices, the invoices are output in the given order. In case there are multiple ways to match a payment entry, [insert your instruction here].

* In the above point, the instruction here refers to the original case pointed out by @cedricdd: Should I allocate 7 3 to A or B? Should I allocate 10 to A or B? You have to explain the basis.

Cases
* As there are no cases where multiple ways of allocation are possible (see the point above), do you intend to add a few more pairs of such cases?

* (Optional) You may add cases where an invoice amount is negative (i.e. the invoice is actually a credit note, which gives a discount or a refund).

* Do you plan to increase the number of cases? I would think it is a good idea. You can include more complex cases where [[N]] and [[M]] are larger and at the same time more combinations / trials and errors are necessary before finding the final answer.

Thanks.
Just to clarify further, the output order of invoices is a different matter from how the invoices should be chosen for matching in the first place. The latter is missing.

For the moment, I will set the difficulty to easy and not add the negative case. Plus, in these cases, there is no way to match a payment entry multiple times.

Could it be good like this ? or do you think it will be better to complexify it ?

Both ways are fine by me: *either* keep it simple (and optionally add a few more simple cases with greater N and M), *or* add complex cases and negative invoice amounts to bump up the difficulty level.

For now, a few more changes in the text (this should be the last round unless you decide to make other changes):

Goal
* Please change "match one entry" to "match each entry".

* Please delete "associate a [[letter]] to this match".

* Please change "Letters are assigned to each match" to "Each match is labelled with a letter".

* Please delete "There is no way to match a payment entry multiple times."

* Please change "That give" to "That gives".

Input
* Please change "a invoice" to "an invoice".

Output
* Please add "per line" after "One match".

* Please change "amount" to "amounts".

Constraints
* Please add this above the current two constraints: "All cases have a unique solution."

(This means there's only one possible way to match each payment entry.)

Thanks.

That's it!

I added this sentence : "Amounts can only be used in one match." cause we did not precise it anywhere.

Into Output, you said to change "amount" to "amounts", but we talk about each line and there is only one payment entry amount per line.

Indeed "amount" fits better in the context.

Would you please slightly change your added sentence: change "Amounts" to "Each amount".

I have no other comments for the time being.

Thank you for following up all along!

Thank you very much for your time and advice!

I learned so much from you, and I hope to do a more complex episode 2.

Have a nice day!
My pleasure. You have a nice day too!

I've understood how bank accounts are associated and I've managed to find a matching patern for invoices, but I don't think it reflects your initial logic.

Beyond providing an example, you had to explain the logic of the puzzle. Understand the stakes of the puzzle

Thanks for your reply!
Is it better now I modified with 5DN1L help ?

It took me a while, but I understood.

There is a lack of diversity in your tests. In almost all cases, the first and last payment entries give fair accounts. You'd need an additional test(+validator) to break this logic. You'll also need an additional test(+validator) where no account is correct in first try. Be sure to also explain all special cases so that there's only one possible solution.

example :
7
3
10
12
4
2
3                  => A 9 - 4 3 2                A 9 - 4 3 2
2                  => B 24 - 14 10    Or    B 24 - 12 10 2 
1                  => C 15 - 12 2 1            C 15 - 14 1
14
9
24
15

You need to set standards, such as sorting invoices from smallest to largest. Then how are the invoices distributed? Do we always try to allocate the largest invoices to the first payment entries, if not, how is this done?

In itself, the addition of the tests I've mentioned isn't all that compulsory for an easy puzzle. However, if you wanted to make an episode 2 of this puzzle with a little more complexity, I think it could be a good line of thought.

Thank you for your reply!

It was my first-line to do something like this, but by talking with 5DN1L about what can be added, I agree with you on doing an episode 2 of this puzzle with negative invoices (credit note), unused payment entries or invoices, and so on.
Great so
